natural problem:
Find the maximum of
\[\sqrt{x + 27} + \sqrt{13 - x} + \sqrt{x}\]for $0 \le x \le 13.$
natural solution: By Cauchy-Schwarz applied to $ \left( 1,\frac{1}{3},\frac{1}{2}\right) $ and $ (\sqrt{x+27},\sqrt{13-x},\sqrt{x}) $, \[\left( 1 + \frac{1}{3} + \frac{1}{2} \right) ((x + 27) + 3(13 - x) + 2x) \ge (\sqrt{x + 27} + \sqrt{13 - x} + \sqrt{x})^2.\]Hence, \[(\sqrt{x + 27} + \sqrt{13 - x} + \sqrt{x})^2 \le 121,\]so $\sqrt{x + 27} + \sqrt{13 - x} + \sqrt{x} \le 11.$
Equality occurs when $x = 9,$ so the maximum value is $\boxed{11}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> x"
and h1 : "x \<le> 13"
shows  "11 = (GREATEST f. \<exists>x. f = sqrt (x + 27) + sqrt (13 - x) + sqrt x)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the maximum of
\[\sqrt{x + 27} + \sqrt{13 - x} + \sqrt{x}\]for $0 \le x \le 13.$ The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 By Cauchy-Schwarz applied to $ \left( 1,\frac{1}{3},\frac{1}{2}\right) $ and $ (\sqrt{x+27},\sqrt{13-x},\sqrt{x}) $, \[\left( 1 + \frac{1}{3} + \frac{1}{2} \right) ((x + 27) + 3(13 - x) + 2x) \ge (\sqrt{x + 27} + \sqrt{13 - x} + \sqrt{x})^2.\]Hence, \[(\sqrt{x + 27} + \sqrt{13 - x} + \sqrt{x})^2 \le 121,\]so $\sqrt{x + 27} + \sqrt{13 - x} + \sqrt{x} \le 11.$
 Equality occurs when $x = 9,$ so the maximum value is $\boxed{11}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> x"
and h1 : "x \<le> 13"
shows  "11 = (GREATEST f. \<exists>x. f = sqrt (x + 27) + sqrt (13 - x) + sqrt x)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the greatest possible value of the function $f(x) = \sqrt{x + 27} + \sqrt{13 - x} + \sqrt{x}$, where $x$ is a real number between 0 and 13 inclusive. The final answer is 11.

theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 13"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = sqrt (x + 27) + sqrt (13 - x) + sqrt x"
shows  "(GREATEST y. \<exists> x. 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 13 \<and> f x = y) = 11"

(* ### Problem

\[\sqrt{x + 27} + \sqrt{13 - x} + \sqrt{x}\]for $0 \le x \le 13.$ The final Answer is 11

 Equality occurs when $x = 9,$ so the maximum value is $\boxed{11}.$
 *)

 *)
